frontmatter.title: Automating deployment of multi-style integrations 300-level live demo

internal.content:
--- title: Automating deployment of multi-style integrations 300-level live demo description: Dent deletion 300-level live demo tabs: [ 'Demo preparation', 'Demo script'] --- export const Title = () => ( Automating deployment of multi-style integrations
300-level live demo ); ![PENDING Dent Deletion banner](./images/TBD) | DEMO OVERVIEW | | | :--- | :--- | | **Scenario overview** | Automating integration deployment using a cloud native approach, to achieve the benefits of greater productivity and simplified operations. This demo uses an insurance brokerage scenario to demonstrate how the deployment of a complex integration solution can be automated using a pipeline. This improves deployment confidence and enables faster and more frequent delivery of changes into production. It also shows how container-based platforms enable operational consistency and automation across those capabilities, simplifying administration of an environment. | | **Demo products** | TBD - Cloud Pak for Integration | | **Demo capabilities** | Application Integration, Enterprise Messaging, API Management | | **Demo guidance** | This demo script has multiple tasks that each have multiple steps. In each step, you have the details about what you need to do (**Actions**), what you can say while delivering this demo step (**Narration**), and what diagrams and screenshots you will see.

This demo script is a suggestion, and you are welcome to customize based on your sales opportunity. Most importantly, practice this demo in advance. If the demo seems easy for you to execute, the customer will focus on the content. If it seems difficult for you to execute, the customer will focus on your delivery. | | **Demo downloads** | Automating deployment of multi-style integrations pptx | | **How to get support** | Contact #itz-techzone-support or techzone.help@ibm.com regarding issues with reserving and provisioning TechZone environments.

Contact #platinumdemos-automation-support regarding issues with setting up and running this demo use case. | ## **DEMO INSTALLATION AND SETUP**
1 - Request your demo environment
Request your demo environment

- Create a ROKS cluster in IBM Cloud
- Install Cloud Pak for Integration on ROKS cluster

**[Go to top](#place1)**
2 - Fork the GitHub repository
This demo uses a Tekton pipeline to build images and deploy them for four App Connect Integration Servers and one MQ server. Now we fork a github repository with all necessary assets for the demo, including the script to create the pipeline.
1. Open a browser and navigate here.

2. If necessary, log in with your personal GitHub account.
3. Click **Fork**. 


4. Select the organization where you want to fork. 

5. The **cp4i-deployment-samples** folder was forked to your organization. You will need its URL in section 5 of this preparation.


**[Go to top](#top)**
3 - Clone the Github repository to your machine
NOTE: To copy the repo you will need to have the Git CLI on your machine. If you don’t have it, follow the installation steps described in this page, based in your operational system.
1. On the forked repo, click **Code** (1) and click **Copy URL button** (2) on the **Clone HTTPS** section.


2. Open your terminal window and execute this command:
``` git clone ```
3. Open the cp4i-deployment-samples folder with this command:
``` cd cp4i-deployment-samples ```
4. You should now see a folder and multiple files. To be able to execute our script files, change the file permission with this command:
``` chmod 755 * ```
**[Go to top](#top)**
4 - Access your ROKS cluster and install the command line tool
In this section, you access your ROKS cluster and install the OpenShift command line tool. If you already have the command line tool, you can proceed to **5 - Access your ROKS cluster using CLI**.
1. Open My reservations in **IBM Technology Zone**.
2. Select your **CP4I ROKS** cluster.


3. Click **Open your Managed OpenShift (ROKS) environment**.


4. Click **OpenShift web console**.


5. On Web console page, click **?** (1), and select **Command line tools** (2). 


6. Follow the links to install the **OpenShift Command Line Interface** (CLI) for your Operational System. 


**[Go to top](#top)**
5 - Access your ROKS cluster using CLI
1. Log in OpenShift cluster using CLI. From the dropdown menu in the upper right of the page, where you see your **username** (1), click **Copy login command** (2).


2. Click **Display Token**.


3. Copy the **login** command.


4. Open your terminal window and paste the **login command** to access your OpenShift cluster.



**[Go to top](#top)**
6 - Set up the parameters to install the pipeline
We’re now going to set up pipeline triggers by linking the GitHub repository to OpenShift pipelines. Now, when you commit a change to GitHub, your OpenShift pipeline runs automatically.
1. Set the namespace to be the correct namespace. It should be cp4i. On your terminal window, run this command:
``` export NAMESPACE=cp4i ```
2. Set the GitHub branch to **main** so the script knows which version of the GitHub artifacts to use.
``` export BRANCH=main ```
3. Set the GitHub repository to use as the URL of your forked repository (made in section 1). You can see it in your browser address bar.


For example, ours is: https://github.com/rosorio/cp4i-deployment-samples.git. Note that rosorio is our github id, yours will be different.
``` export FORKED_REPO=https://github.com//cp4i-deployment-samples.git ```


**[Go to top](#top)**
7 - Create the pipeline
Follow these steps to create the pipeline in OpenShift Pipeline page. 
1. In the **cp4i-deployment-samples** folder, open the **DrivewayDentDeletion/Operators folder**.
``` cd DrivewayDentDeletion/Operators ```

2. Create the pipeline by running this command.
``` ./cicd-apply-test-apic-pipeline.sh -n $NAMESPACE -r $FORKED_REPO -b $BRANCH ```

3. Return to the OpenShift Console. On the left menu, open **Pipelines**, then **Pipelines** to see what has been added.

4. On the **Project combo box** (1), select **cp4i** (2).

5. There should be two pipelines.

**[Go to top](#top)**
8 - Download the BAR file
In this section, you download a BAR file to be used during the demo. 
1. Open this URL in your browser: https://github.com/amarIBM/hello-world/blob/master/HttpEchoApp.bar
2. Click the **Download** button. 


Great! You are ready to present the demo.
**[Go to top](#top)**

Click [here](/300-business-automation-predictive-decisioning/demo-script) to go to **Demo Script** on the next tab. (actual PDF to be produced when demo and script are approved)
